awd_titl_txt: Trustees of Columbia University in the City of New York/Langseth Oceanographic Instrumentation
awd_abstract_narration:
A proposal is made to fund instrumentation on the R/V Marcus Langseth, a 235’ Global seismic vessel with general oceanographic capabilities. The vessel is owned by Columbia University and operated by Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University under a cooperative agreement with NSF. The Langseth is unique in the Academic Fleet in that it provides a combination of capabilities for imaging the oceans, the seafloor and the solid earth beneath the sea. It is the only vessel in the world dedicated to academic research that can conduct 3D seismic surveys as well as extended offset 2D surveys. The tuned, linear source array, consisting of up to 36 airguns, with a total capacity of 6,600 cu in is also unique asset of this vessel.
All of the requested equipment in this proposal is for upgrading existing systems. Instrumentation requested in this proposal includes:

Seamap BuoyLink 4DX GNSS Source Tracking system	$224,016
Cisco Meraki computer Network vessel-wide upgrade	$36,135
Seamap Near Field Hydrophones and HVRU	$43,215
						$303,366
Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 19-602). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF).  The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The R/V Marcus G. Langseth is a global class vessel in the US Academic Research Fleet that serves as National Seismic Imaging Facility.  This research vessel has significant 2D and 3D seismic imaging capability that allows it too provide detailed information deep below ocean seafloor to scientists that study the materials and geologic processes that cannot be directly observed.  To collect this data, the Langseth must tow both a seismic source and long hydrophone (listening devices) streamers that collect the acoustic reflections that bounce off sediment/rock layers in the subseafloor to create an image using specialized software.  The towed streamers are made up of a variety of different sections at the ship that allow up to 12-15km (7.4 to 9.3miles) long streamers to be towed safely from the vessel and for data from the hydrophones to flow  to the ship's computers for processing.  The towed seismic source consists of 4 identical arrays that have a total of 28 element (7/array) and a total air volume of 6600 cubic inches.

The 2023 Ocean Instrumentation award funded new critical seismic source positioning and quality control equipment for this towed source array. The seismic source onboard Langseth is obviously a key component of our multi-channel seismic system and for any active source Ocean Bottom Sensor expedition.  The acquisition of the BuoyLink 4DX seismic source positioning system provides an advanced relative GPS (RGPS) solution for proper positioning of our source array and sensors.  Combined with this new source positioning system for the Langseth seismic source we have added new additional Near Field Hydrophone (NFH) units and an onboard calibration kit.  These additional NFH units have allowed us to install one unit per sound source element and this provides a significant improvement in positioning quality and source modeling of the array. In addition, this award funded an important computer network upgrade to our Meraki system for networking and security hardware. This upgrades improves and simplifies our network monitoring, increases bandwidth and access in more spaces around the ship.

 


Last Modified: 02/22/2024
Modified by: Sean M Higgins

To collect this data, the Langseth must tow both a seismic source and long hydrophone (listening devices) streamers that collect the acoustic reflections that bounce off sediment/rock layers in the subseafloor to create an image using specialized software. The 2023 Ocean Instrumentation award funded new critical seismic source positioning and quality control equipment for this towed source array. This upgrades improves and simplifies our network monitoring, increases bandwidth and access in more spaces around the ship.
